measured_by: 0–100 moral rightness rating scale in realistic moral dilemmas
justification: Participants were asked, “How morally right is it for you to push the man off the ladder? (0 = Not at all morally right, 100 = Completely morally right),” indicating that moral rightness was captured with a 0–100 rating scale.

measured_by: Yes/No action choice in 13 realistic moral dilemmas
justification: Each vignette ended with the question “Do you push the man off the ladder? (Yes/No),” and similar prompts across 13 dilemmas, so the binary action choice records whether a participant adopted the CBR-based or rule-based option.

After seeing the consequence, participants rated it: “How good or bad is this outcome? (-100 = Extremely bad, 0 = Neutral, 100 = Extremely good),” demonstrating that outcome evaluation was measured with a −100 to 100 scale.

measured_by: Proportion of CBR-based choices across dilemmas
justification: Figures and analyses refer to the “observed proportion of CBR-based choices” and use this proportion to model learning, showing that the share of CBR selections served as the metric for reliance on cost-benefit reasoning.
